Rolf Steiner.Action: Corporal Steiner is on a reconnaissance patrol despite risks; Meyer expresses confidence that Steiner will return.
Described by others as a first rate soldier despite lack of respect, indicating strong competence but contentious interpersonal relations.
Described as a first rate soldier despite being a problem and having a lack of respect.
Returns from the field and is immediately recognized with a promotion to Senior Sergeant, indicating recognition of capability and leadership.
Remains noticeably quiet while others joke and react around him.
Responds to Captain Stransky's disappointment with almost nonchalant unconcern and mild apology.
Responds to Captain Stransky's inquiry almost nonchalantly and slackly comes to attention, showing lack of formal respect or enthusiasm.
Is noticeably quiet during men’s half-hearted banter and does not engage to boost morale or assert presence.
Shows no visible reaction to promotion, responding with 'No, sir' and a dry sense of humor about casualties.
Politely refuses a cigarette from Captain Stransky.
Receives promotion to Senior Sergeant but shows no visible surprise or emotional reaction, indicating steady composure and confidence.
Refuses cigarette offered by Captain Stransky even after stressful events, demonstrating self-control and discipline.
Gives very terse and blunt answers in the report about the enemy and casualties, suggesting practical honesty but potentially lack of elaboration or tactical insight.
Decides not to risk the entire platoon for one missing man, prioritizing group safety over an individual.
Responds to Stransky's criticism with a dry, apologetic but somewhat indifferent 'Sorry, sir. I'll try to do better next time.'
Leaves German guns behind to carry captured Russian guns, believing the Russian weapons to be superior despite military expectations.
Grins mirthlessly when reminded about the sacrifices for German equipment, revealing a cynical attitude.
Decides not to look for the missing man to avoid risking the entire platoon's safety.
Calmly acknowledges his failure without excuses or defensiveness.
Chooses to leave their own superior German guns to carry captured Russian guns, believing the latter are better—contradicting conventional wisdom.
Demonstrates practical judgment in prioritizing the platoon's safety over the missing man, showing situational awareness.
Displays knowledge and critical thinking by disputing accepted opinions about equipment quality.
Responds wryly and ironically to Meyer about someone's dislike for him, saying 'Too bad. I'm crazy about him.'
Laconically asserts his ability to survive many commanders including Stransky.
States with confidence that he has survived many battalion commanders and will survive Stransky too.
Responds wryly and laconic, showing calm composure facing potential conflict or dislike.
Throws away German guns to make room for Russian guns because they are better and the men know it.
Walks watching men digging in, takes a long moment looking up at the sky before entering the bunker.
Writes an enormously valuable report that his superior intends to personally transmit to the General.
Explains confidently and clearly his decision to replace German guns with superior Russian guns, showing knowledge and conviction.
Is unpunctual and unsoldierly as noted by Brandt, which may suggest some disregard for protocol or discipline.
Refuses a safer staff post out of solidarity with his men.
Responds dryly and somewhat dismissively to Brandt's confusion, indicating a lack of openness.
Leaves without protest when ordered out, showing respect for authority despite tension.
Shouts at Maag to question his retreat and prevent abandonment of post.
Pushes Maag back into the hole when Maag tries to leave post in danger, then huddles together with Maag until Russian machine guns quiet down.
Leads counterattack at risk, stays to direct fire and sends up flare to illuminate enemy positions showing concern for comrades and mission success.
Leads his men cautiously and thoughtfully, considering the overall tactical situation before acting.
Warns his men with ironic humor, acknowledging the pressure they face ('Remember, the eyes of the entire German nation are upon you').
Makes a decisive and clear command encouraging his men to stick together and use hand grenades effectively.
Carefully assesses the size and position of the enemy column before deciding on a tactical response.
Decides not to fire immediately to avoid compromising the planned counter-attack, showing foresight.
Uses flares to alert friendly forces and surprise the enemy, demonstrating tactical skill.
Leads the men with clear, confident orders and initiates a counter-attack against a larger force.
Shows hesitation when first confronted with the enemy's strength.
Makes sarcastic remarks to Kruger despite Kruger helping him, indicating a rough interaction but also acknowledging assistance indirectly.
Shows concern for wounded Anselm by urging him to go to the Field Hospital.
Questions Anselm sarcastically about who they were shooting at, indicating alertness and situational awareness.
Arrives at the bunker with a head bandage yet immediately inquires about the signal failure, showing promptness and leadership despite injury.
Engages in sarcastic exchange with Kruger during a stressful moment, possibly undermining unit cohesion and communication.
Accepts responsibility and reports losses candidly to Stransky, showing accountability.
Allows Gertrud to pull him back from drowning, then reacts with rage and knocks her arm away.
Suddenly seizes Gertrud and forces her to the ground, pulling her blouse off one shoulder; she stops struggling but shows no compliance.
After the forced contact, he abruptly releases Gertrud and watches silently without speaking, then harshly tells her to keep away.
Struggles physically and falls face down in water, makes no effort to rise, showing physical weakness and loss of control.
After recovering, washes blood from face and attempts to regain composure, shows a degree of self-awareness and determination despite condition.
Seizes Gertrud and forces her to the ground, behaves aggressively and coercively, showing poor judgment and loss of control.
Releases Gertrud abruptly and stands silently watching her, indicating internal conflict but no clear intelligent or skillful resolution.
Mocks Nurse Gertrud with harsh laughter and a tiny bow, then leaves abruptly.
Hesitates before entering another room, listens carefully, then quietly opens the door.
Enters Inge's dark bedroom uninvited, asks for aspirin while invading her privacy.
Grips Inge's shoulders tightly against her protests and physically restrains her when she wants to leave.
Avoids Inge's kiss and picks her up carrying her to bed despite her resistance and threats to scream.
Hesitates at his bedroom door, listens carefully before entering an adjacent room, checks surroundings before proceeding.
Enters a dark bedroom quietly and with awareness, employing stealth and caution.
Engages with Inge in a controlling and forceful manner, ignoring her protests and attempting to assert dominance.
Walks away from Inge after a casual, insufficient kiss, causing her distress and sobbing; stands embarrassed and remorseful but does not attempt to comfort her.
Shows emotional awkwardness and fails to communicate effectively in intimate situations, leading to interpersonal conflict.
Faces Ilse with a steady greeting, acknowledges complicated past, causing Ilse distress.
Shows no visible warmth or consolation when Ilse sobs and flees; expression remains grim and expressionless.
Attempts to engage Ilse after being prompted despite preoccupation and tension.
Turns toward the bar upon hearing about Ilse and immediately recognizes her presence, showing situational awareness.
Approaches Ilse steadily and with control, maintaining composure despite the emotional situation.
Engages Ilse with calm, controlled speech displaying emotional restraint in a difficult personal encounter.
Shows a grim, expressionless face to Gertrud, which suggests emotional detachment but also possible coldness or emotional complexity.
Does not respond to Klaus' teasing remark about his effect on women, choosing silence instead of deflecting or engaging.
Shares a personal and humiliating story honestly with Gertrud.
Refuses to be brutal to Ilse despite her actions against him.
Maintains distance and silence when Gertrud seeks connection, leaves without further engagement.
Writes a detailed confession and takes responsibility for a difficult personal situation involving a court martial and penal battalion sentence.
Shows emotional vulnerability and humiliation, indicating self-awareness but possibly undermining confident leadership.
Insists on obtaining a signed confession to clarify events, showing methodical and strategic thinking.
Turns away from Gertrud's plea and leaves, which might suggest difficulty in managing interpersonal situations compassionately.
Shows no empathy or kindness, physically abuses Ilse by holding her head under water, demanding a confession.
Confronts Ilse with a written accusation and demands a confession, showing clear intention and confidence.
Physically assaults Ilse by dragging her into water and holding her head under, using aggression to gain control.
Catches the flashlight Ilse knocks away quickly, showing alertness and physical capability.
Uses intimidation and physical force rather than reasoned dialogue or persuasion, which may indicate a reliance on brute force over skillful negotiation.
Forces Ilse to sign a paper under duress, shows no pity as she leaves distressed.
After obtaining the signed paper, tears it up and lets it go, showing disinterest in pursuing the matter.
Silent, sincere embrace with Gertrud, showing tenderness and mutual support.
Thrusts the pencil into Ilse's hand and insists she sign the paper to get her statement, showing firmness and control in a tense situation.
Examines the signed paper closely and seems deep in thought, indicating careful consideration and intelligence.
Tears the signed paper into tiny scraps and throws them into the water, indicating a deliberate choice to discard evidence and resign from clearing his name.
Shrugs when asked why he discarded the paper and says he is not interested anymore in clearing his name, showing possible loss of resolve or disengagement.
Sits close to Gertrud, resting his head on her shoulder and sharing a smile; shows gentle and affectionate behavior.
Expresses moderate regret and sorrow about the death of a comrade ('I'm sorry he's gone') despite not being particularly close.
Calls out a fellow officer's report as a lie, showing a critical and possibly confrontational stance.
Reflects reasonably on the death of Dorn, acknowledging the soldier's competence and expressing appropriate regret.
Critically evaluates and exposes the false report by Captain Stransky, showing awareness and honesty about battlefield events.
Accepts Gertrud's comfort, allowing intimacy and showing vulnerability by resting his head on her and kissing her, permitting closeness and emotional support.
Expresses deep pessimism and isolation by stating 'It'll never be over. Not for me.' and falling silent, showing inward struggle but no outreach or sharing beyond close relationship.
Recognizes the falseness of a report praising others and implicitly contrasts it with his own front-line presence, indicating awareness and insight.
Declines to immediately return from the front line despite being informed of a possible leave, showing resolve and commitment but possible recklessness.
Shows emotional vulnerability and hesitation when faced with the chance to rest, possibly indicating inner conflict but also thoughtful restraint.
No direct action showing tactical or leadership skill in this excerpt, remaining passive and contemplative rather than active.
Slowly approaches Muller without eagerness to leave, indicating reluctance or hesitation about going to the front.
Exchanges brief, seemingly sarcastic words with Inge; calls her 'a pig' but neither hostile nor affectionate; does not open the envelope, showing emotional reservation.
Allows Inge to read a personal letter aloud without protest or withdrawal, showing some tolerance and passive acceptance.
Stands outside the rest home, waiting and looking up and down the street with apparent purpose and patience.
Walks slowly up to Muller, showing a lack of urgency or anxiety about moving with the others who are eager to go.
Does not open the envelope immediately and does not react openly to Inge's reading of the letter, showing emotional control or hesitation.
Snatches and crumples a heartfelt letter, showing emotional suppression.
Throws away the letter and impulsively jumps on a wrong truck heading to the front.
Walks among strangers with only cursory acknowledgment, indicating detachment.
Is greeted warmly by comrades in the bunker who call his name repeatedly.
Responds to newcomer Zoll's angry criticism with calm sarcasm and humor, easing tension and eliciting laughter.
Refers to the newcomer Zoll by name and politely corrects him, showing an effort to engage sincerely despite disagreement.
Maintains a stony, unemotional face when insulted, showing little openness or friendliness in that moment.
Responds to Kruger's insult with calm and confident remarks, shows awareness of his situation by knowing he was home for two weeks and choosing to stay.
Handles newcomer Zoll's challenge with dry wit and sarcasm, diffusing tension and maintaining control of the group.
Invites the newcomer to memorize his correct serial number to avoid confusion or trouble, indicating self-assurance and control.
Does not visibly react with anger or defensiveness to criticism and maintains composure.
Shows eagerness and respect towards Captain Stransky, indicating professionalism and readiness to engage with command.
Reluctantly obeys an order to sit down despite apparent tension.
Expresses disagreement calmly and respectfully about class-based superiority.
Keeps facial expression composed, not showing vulnerability or friendliness during tense exchange.
Maintains composure and counters Stransky's argument calmly and intelligently without losing his temper.
Reluctantly sits only after being explicitly ordered, showing some hesitance or resistance to authority.
Shows awareness of the underlying political/social dynamics and directly challenges them with a reasoned argument.
Does not quickly reveal his inner feelings when Stransky tries to manipulate him emotionally, indicating self-control.
Maintains composure and steadiness despite aggressive insults; controls his anger and responds quietly and calmly.
Challenges superior (Stransky) on grounds of equality rather than submitting submissively.
Uses cold, impertinent language implying confrontation rather than friendliness.
Engages in a tense confrontation confidently, maintains composure and controls his emotions despite provocation.
Refuses to submit to Stransky’s authority, challenges unfair treatment calmly and assertively.
Uses steady and quiet voice to deliver a warning, indicating self-control and confidence under pressure.
Jumps into the pit to start shoveling despite being up to his knees in mud.
Responds laconic and polite to Brandt's inquiries and accepts cigarette gesture.
Corrects Brandt honestly about who led the counterattack, despite potential tension.
Responds promptly and decisively by jumping into the pit and starts shoveling despite being up to his knees in mud.
Appears sleepy and somewhat disoriented in the outer room of the command post but nevertheless recovers quickly when called and walks in confidently.
Answers Brandt's questions laconically and accurately corrects misinformation about the counterattack leadership.
States confidently that he witnessed Lieutenant Meyer reporting to Captain Stransky and denies seeing the Captain at the counterattack, showing trust in his own observations and honesty.
Refuses to immediately confirm or deny seeing Captain Stransky, asking for time to think over his statement.
Keeps differences with Captain Stransky private and does not engage in open hostility with Brandt despite tension.
Responds to Brandt’s accusations with a growl, indicating frustration but not outright aggression.
Hesitates to confirm his testimony and avoids direct answers when questioned by Brandt about Captain Stransky's presence.
Stands by his original testimony despite pressure, indicating some resolve in his position.
Admits to hatred openly and refuses to fake positive feelings towards his superiors, expressing sincere, if harsh, emotions.
Speaks violently and ungratefully to Captain Kiesel and Colonel Brandt, showing hostility rather than friendliness or tolerance.
Shows internal struggle in resisting harsh words, indicating some self-awareness and conflicted emotions.
Responds defiantly and emotionally to criticism from superiors, expressing hatred and refusal to rely on them.
Stops short after a rash statement, showing immediate regret but failing to recover or control the situation.
Communicates the rear guard order to the men calmly, encourages them to feel proud.
Responds to Schnurrbart's cynical remark with a dry, somewhat bitter comment about picking enemies more carefully.
Platoon abandons bunker and takes up forward position promptly on intelligence report.
Platoon abandons their bunker and leaves to take up a forward position, cutting their own telephone wires before the enemy arrives.
His platoon's retreat causes concern but is explained away as justified and skillful by subordinates, showing initiative and tactical awareness.
Returns to the group after a hard situation, checks on all men being present and no deserters, then calmly addresses the situation with a map and strategic planning.
Returns to the group drenched but shows concern for the group's status and quickly moves to take stock by consulting the map and asking strategic questions about terrain and enemy positions.
Considers terrain challenges (marshy area, stream with no bridge) and questions the feasibility of movement through it, showing tactical awareness.
Dismisses suggestion to take the highway without directly explaining his reasoning at first but indicates awareness of heavy enemy presence on the highway, showing situational intelligence.
Uses confident language and commands attention when giving situation updates and leading discussion, demonstrating assertiveness linked to competence.
Uses sarcasm toward Kern when others express concern (sardonically to Kern: 'There! Do you feel better?') and bluntly states the hopelessness of their situation.
Despite his sarcastic and pessimistic remarks, he takes the initiative to lead the group by opening the door and motioning the men to start the exodus.
Kicks the stove over, spilling embers before leaving, possibly expressing frustration or anger in a non-constructive way.
Complies with the group's movement and silently leads them out in difficult weather conditions, showing a sense of responsibility and solidarity.
Devises a plan to cross a highway despite enemy presence, demonstrating awareness of conditions and possible methods (waiting for gaps, tunneling, or pole vaulting metaphorically).
Responds sarcastically to Kern’s pessimism but still takes charge, opening the door and leading the men out, signaling decisiveness and leadership.
Kicks over the stove to spill embers before leaving, possibly a tactical or symbolic action indicating discipline or signaling the inevitability of their dangerous situation.
Acknowledges the dire situation repeatedly ('finished'), but continues to pursue action rather than paralysis, showing realistic but proactive mindset.
Slaps cigarette from Zoll's mouth to prevent revealing their position, speaks angrily but protects group
Signals the men to stop and then to follow, taking charge calmly under pressure
Stops the men upon sensing danger and commands them to halt.
Forcefully reprimands a comrade for careless behavior that could jeopardize the group.
Leads a small team away stealthily into darkness to presumably scout or address the threat.
Coldly interrupts and dismisses Zoll's attempt to raise concern for mistreatment of a comrade, tells him to mind his own business and ignores the issue.
Shows quiet confidence and leadership, signaling the men silently to prepare, but does not engage warmly with them.
Leads the men confidently through the forest, showing triumph in his eyes as they converge on his position.
Holds up his hand for quiet and assesses the situation calmly as the sound of enemy vehicles approaches.
Responds coldly and firmly to Zoll's challenge about soldier equality, maintaining control of the group dynamic.
Dismisses Zoll's concerns brusquely, possibly alienating a subordinate who is trying to raise an issue.
Disobeys orders by moving his platoon from the bunker despite instructions to stay until dark.
Disobeys direct orders to stay put until dark, moving his platoon despite explicit instructions.
Successfully leads his platoon through difficult terrain under pressure and enemy threat, showing endurance and tactical skill.
Reluctantly agrees to call a rest for the men despite his own drive to continue.
Digs his boot into a wounded comrade's side and physically drags him to his feet.
Confronts Zoll with quiet verbal contempt rather than empathy, calling him a coward.
Recognizes the need for rest but insists on continuing despite exhaustion, showing awareness of limitations yet determination.
Prods a clearly exhausted and uncooperative soldier (Zoll) to retrieve lost ammunition, showing leadership and focus on mission needs.
Responds to Zoll's hostile reaction with quiet criticism rather than escalating conflict, indicating emotional control and composure.
Fails to address the underlying causes of his men's exhaustion or consider alternative actions beyond forcing them onward, suggesting possible rigidity.
Calmly disarms Zoll by taking his rifle away, easing tension among the men.
Calls Zoll a coward quietly but does not escalate conflict.
Gives clear orders to the men, organizes them for the next move.
Dismisses Kruger's objections sharply with 'Shut up!'
Calmly disarms a hostile Zoll by taking the rifle from his hands at close range, demonstrating control and authority.
Correctly assesses the difficult terrain by climbing a tree for reconnaissance and noting the swamps, reeds, and water.
Plans the next day's march before dawn, showing strategic foresight despite difficult terrain.
Overrules objections and insists on marching thirty miles north to the road instead of staying close to a known point, indicating confidence in his judgment even under dissent.
Encourages men to boil dirty water to make it drinkable despite complaints, making a joke about their 'pig's stomachs'.
Organizes the men to make soup and gather wood, assigning practical tasks.
Attempts to settle the issue of sentry duty by asking for a volunteer, showing concern for group safety.
Proposes boiling dirty water and using tree bark as food, showing resourcefulness and practical problem-solving in a difficult situation.
Insists on orderly behavior and responsibility among exhausted men, attempting to organize sentry duty despite reluctance.
Does not force or coerce volunteers but attempts to encourage, showing leadership though limited in effectiveness.
Leaves abruptly without informing others where he is going, causing unease among the men.
His voice is heard commanding to let the fighting men continue, indicating assertive control over the situation.
Interrogates an old Russian guarding a bridge, puts gun muzzle to his head to force an answer.
Decides to personally execute the old Russian prisoner to make it quick and clean instead of delegating the task.
Shows a brief moment of physical sickness (vomiting) after the killing, indicating some level of personal discomfort or remorse.
Mentions admiring the old man moments before deciding to kill him, indicating a conflicted and somewhat respectful attitude.
Coldly decides to kill the Russian prisoner without apparent attempt to find alternatives or show mercy.
Decides to personally carry out the killing efficiently rather than delegating, indicating decisiveness and willingness to accept difficult tasks.
Takes calculated risks by proceeding despite possible danger of enemies nearby.
Demonstrates calmness and controlled demeanor in a tense and morally difficult situation.

His physical reaction (throwing up) after the act shows human vulnerability and emotional impact, which might slightly reduce perception of cold professional competence but reflects realism rather than failure.
His remark about not worrying about enemy numbers suggests confidence and pragmatism about mission requirements.
Emphasizes the importance of teamwork and expresses concern that no enemy escapes, showing seriousness about collective responsibility.
Gives clear and ordered instructions to his men, showing leadership and trust in their capabilities.
Focuses intensely on the tactical objective without any expressed empathy or emotional connection to his men or enemy.
Formulates a clear, strategic plan to smoke enemies out with grenades and cut off all escape routes, emphasizing the importance of no one escaping behind enemy lines.
Assigns men thoughtfully to cover escape routes with machine gun positions and leads the majority of the platoon himself, demonstrating tactical awareness and leadership.
Insists that all enemies must be captured or killed to prevent alerting others, showing insight into the broader operational consequences.
Watches Zoll's childish game with curiosity but responds with sarcasm and cynicism rather than warmth or friendliness.
Commands men to proceed with mission while mocking Zoll's superstition, showing impatience and lack of empathy.
Maintains an expressionless face and ignores Zoll's vulnerable and apologetic demeanor.
Observes Zoll's distracted behavior and remains focused on the mission, calmly takes control and plans the attack on the guard.
Shows patience and careful aim while preparing to shoot, indicating skill and control under pressure.
Uses sarcasm and dismissiveness toward Zoll's childish game, which may reflect a lack of empathy but does not affect mission competence.
Immediately fires at the guard on the bridge to protect his men and forces the enemy to retreat.
Commands his men to stop shooting after clearing the immediate threat, showing control to prevent unnecessary violence.
Questions Kruger sharply for leaving his post, emphasizing duty and responsibility despite stressful circumstances.
Shoots accurately to incapacitate the guard on the bridge, enabling his men to advance.
Immediately commands his men to lie flat and to stop shooting at the silent house, showing control and tactical caution.
Doubts Zoll's hope that the house is empty, showing realistic assessment of the situation.
Questions Kruger sharply and critically for abandoning his post, demonstrating leadership and concern for discipline under pressure.
Decides to treat captured female soldiers as prisoners of war despite the risks involved.
Firmly insists on the necessity of potentially killing unarmed prisoners to prevent them escaping and informing the enemy.
Kicks open the front door and immediately assesses a dangerous situation with calm decisiveness.
Orders Kern to stay outside and fire one shot if anyone comes, showing tactical caution and control.
Recognizes that the captured women, though unarmed, are regular enemy troops and insists on treating them as prisoners of war.
Considers and insists on the harsh measure of shooting the prisoners to prevent any from escaping and jeopardizing their mission.
Orders water to clean the wounded woman's wound despite others' skepticism and then tends to her injury with apparent care.
Insists on treating the wounded woman despite the apparent contradiction in orders, showing practical skill and decisiveness in administering first aid.
Questions sources of information and uses interrogation (through Kruger) to verify the truthfulness of the prisoners, demonstrating tactical inquiry and cautious judgment.
Maintains control of the situation by sharply commanding Anselm to bring water despite confusion and resistance, showing authoritative confidence.
Pushes the old Russian wounded soldier toward the women and motions for him to lie down, showing concern for his safety.
Commands Zoll to shoot any woman who starts trouble among the group.
Dismissive and somewhat harsh when telling Zoll not to be so eager to eat despite scarcity.
Pushes the old Russian in the direction of the women and motions for him to lie down, taking charge of a tense situation calmly and decisively.
Orders Zoll to shoot any woman who starts trouble, showing a strict control over discipline and foresight about potential dangers.
Responds sharply to Zoll's casual question about eating, focusing on mission priorities over personal needs.
Identifies the sound of a gunshot accurately and responds promptly by heading to the scene.
Examines the wounded Kern, quickly assesses the severity ('He's probably finished') and instructs others to assist.
Kicks open door abruptly in response to hearing whimpering; confronts Zoll sharply and menacingly with gun raised.
Shows concern for the girl whimpering by stopping her distress through his intervention.
Accuses Zoll of negligence and threatening lives, indicating a strong sense of justice and responsibility.
Acts coldly and threateningly toward Zoll, refusing mercy despite Zoll's protestations.
Violently assaults Zoll by hitting him across the face and forcibly locks him in a wardrobe, threatening to shoot if he makes a sound.
Shows stern control of the situation ensuring the girl's safety by forcing Zoll into confinement and removing potential danger.
Insists Zoll open wardrobe to check for a weapon, showing tactical caution.
Physically overpowers Zoll and confines him in the empty wardrobe to neutralize a potential threat.
Moves and topples the wardrobe to reveal the hidden girl, demonstrating situational awareness and decisiveness.
Threatens Zoll to keep silence, maintaining control over the situation.
Kneels and looks at wounded woman, asks how she feels.
Dismisses the men’s find sarcastically ('You picked a lovely time to go souvenir hunting.')
Admiring the captured Russian map as a 'work of art' and acknowledges its value.
Orders Kruger to tell the captured Russian women to undress for the mission despite men’s discomfort.
Analyzes captured enemy map quickly and accurately to identify enemy positions and plan a crossing at the best spot, showing situational awareness and tactical insight.
Commands the men to have the women undress and wear enemy uniforms to facilitate the planned operation under cover of darkness, demonstrating practical and decisive leadership.
Responds with a sarcastic remark about the timing of the troops' souvenir hunting, showing sharp wit but slight impatience which may affect group morale.
Urgently suggests hurrying to avoid Russian attack, showing concern for group's safety.
Responds to worries about friendly fire with a challenge invoking national pride, showing firmness but little empathy.
Tells the old Russian woman to wait and look elsewhere without further explanation, showing limited patience or compassion.
Inspects the wounded woman’s bandage and honestly assesses her condition, showing practical concern.
Remains expressionless and makes a grim decision to leave when the wounded woman’s fate is clear, showing detachment.
Leads men into the woods confidently, disappearing from women's view, indicating command and initiative.
Fails to respond or rescue Zoll who is locked inside the wardrobe, despite being called frantically.
Turns a look of scorn upon Anselm when he hysterically suggests shooting Kern, causing Anselm to immediately subside, shame-faced.
Reassures Kern not to be afraid, saying 'we're all with you.'
Considers holding a service for the dead man, to respect Schnurrbart's beliefs and avoid political implications.
Speaks grimly and cynically about God being a sadist.
Reflects on how Kern would have been forgotten if died at home, urges men not to forget him and not to feel too sorry for him.
Decides not to bury Kern but leave him for the Russians, displaying pragmatic coldness.
Comforts the injured Kern by holding a flashlight close to his face and telling him not to be afraid, showing calm presence in crisis.
Realistically assesses Kern's condition bluntly and calmly states he is dead, avoiding false hope.
Decides pragmatically against burying Kern due to lack of time, showing tactical awareness.
Organizes a brief service despite personal cynicism, showing leadership and consideration for morale and political implications.
Expresses cynical view of God as a sadist, reveals internal bitterness but maintains control of the group.
Shouts clearly to identify his group and prevent friendly fire despite danger.
Commands his men to bring in the presumably dead Schnurrbart and Anselm despite the risks, showing respect and concern for comrades.
Fixes a steely, savage glance at Triebig, confronting him harshly for firing on their own men.

Quickly recovers from being nearly shot by Triebig and immediately takes command, demanding answers and ordering his men to find the missing Schnurrbart and Anselm despite knowing they are likely dead.
Fixes a steely, commanding glance on Triebig, showing confidence and authority in a tense situation.
Acts decisively and clearly in confusion and danger, maintaining control and pushing his men forward.
Orders the burial of the dead soldiers decently despite the tension and urgency.
Slaps Triebig hard across the cheek to silence his hysterical outburst.
Shows no surprise at Triebig's hysteria and remains silent, maintaining a stern demeanor.
Maintains silence and a steady, unrelenting stare when Triebig breaks down hysterically, showing emotional control and command presence.
Slaps Triebig to silence him during his hysterical outburst, taking decisive action to restore order and discipline immediately.
Orders wounded soldiers to be taken back to Battalion and buried decently, demonstrating practical leadership and concern for duty and morale.
Does not verbally respond to Triebig's pleas or attempt to explain, which may indicate aloofness or lack of communication but also could reflect tactical silence.
Commands Triebig aggressively with gun pointed at him, threatening to shoot if he does not obey; shows no hesitation in forcing compliance through intimidation.
Promises not to shoot Triebig if he obeys promptly, suggesting a minimal attempt to reassure him despite the threat.
Commands Triebig decisively with a gun to his ribs, controls the situation firmly and uses a flare to illuminate the target before engaging the enemy.
Wryly acknowledges his very small platoon (just himself and another man) with a hint of dry humor.
Accepts cigarette offered by Kiesel without hesitation, indicating some social openness and ease.
Politely requests a few hours of sleep before making his report, showing respect and consideration for formalities.
Accepts suggestion to rest before reporting, thanks Kiesel politely.
Runs madly toward airstrip, seemingly impulsive and possibly dangerous toward Stransky.
Requests a few hours' sleep before making an important report, showing awareness of the need to be rested for clear thinking.
Runs frantically toward the air strip possibly to intercept or stop Stransky, indicating impulsive behavior that may risk jeopardizing the mission.
Points a gun at Captain Stransky and threatens him, showing coldness and menace.
Expresses a deep internal conflict about life and death, revealing vulnerability and sincerity.
Confronts Captain Stransky with a Luger at close range, commands him to surrender despite the risk, showing decisiveness and control.
Expresses awareness of consequences and evaluates the situation quickly, deciding to act swiftly on a heavily traveled road.
Admits to being torn between will to live and will to die, indicating internal conflict impacting his judgment.
Mentions prior failures and survival against odds but now willing to die, demonstrating a complex mindset that could impair practical competence.
Pulls a grenade and threatens to kill himself and Captain Stransky in a fatal act to force a situation.
Pulls a grenade and insists on sharing a suicide with Captain Stransky, counting down confidently and deliberately before the grenade explodes.
